body:
The user still needs to enable them by setting the filetpyes.
Also make efm less noisy by passing -q.

comment_data.body:
uh... what's the plan here? why aren't these maintained in https://github.com/mattn/efm-langserver itself?

It's easy to imagine this config becoming a "configs collection" inside of nvim-lspconfig (which is itself a "configs collection"), reinventing null-ls or [none-ls](https://github.com/nvimtools/none-ls.nvim).

There are 100s of formatters and linters out there.

I was not aware of that, thanks!

(Closing as that is better.)
Thanks but that one does not do formatters from what I see.

For formatting: https://github.com/stevearc/conform.nvim

There's also https://github.com/chrisgrieser/nvim-rulebook which is an "all-around helper" that I've been meaning to try.
Thanks for all the pointer but currently it feels still like efm (with the efmls-configs-nvim) is the better option. Or do you have other reasons?
Perhaps those are worth mentioning in the docstring for this config.

Mentioning at least https://github.com/creativenull/efmls-configs-nvim sound good.

@polyzen I just switched to nvim-lint and conform :). (somehow efm broke..)

comment_regular_data.body:
This looks like a useful sample for people to use as a starting point. So it's fine. But don't think it's scalable.

Will merge after the lint issues are fixed.

repo.description: Quickstart configurations for the Nvim LSP client
repo.name: nvim-lspconfig

title: feat(efm): add some default settings
